“You are your best advocate. Your voice matters, and your story is important.” – Michelle Obama.

“Getting our Voice Heard” – we all need help with this at times, isn’t it? That’s what our recent WISE Program ( Women’s Initiative for Success and Empowerment) focused on. 
 
Oliver Skagerlind, our Chief Digital Information Officer joined us to engage with our Women folks and share his perspective on Women’s Empowerment in the Workplace. 

He spoke about his personal story, the influence of women leadership on his career journey and some key traits that help women navigate through some common workplace challenges to pave their way to success, whilst balancing their multiple responsibilities. 

Our WISE Program is a 4-month development journey, tailored for women at DAMAC, addressing the distinctive challenges they encounter in personal and professional domains and enabling them to flourish in their roles.

This is a masterclass you don’t want to miss. 

Watching Roger Federer speak to university students made me sit up and wonder—can we admire and respect him even more than we already do? 

His words took me back to every master I’ve ever seen in action—whether on screen, in an office, or on the sports field. 

Federer, one of the greatest athletes of all time, didn’t just play tennis—he created magic with a racquet in hand. But through his speech, he reminds us that what seemed like magic was actually the product of relentless dedication and an unshakable work ethic. 

People thought he barely broke a sweat. Yet behind what the world saw as effortless genius was a man who spent countless hours practicing, strategizing, and failing. 

That effortlessness? It’s a myth. 

Much like Virat Kohli’s cover drive or Rohit Sharma’s pull shot. We assume it's pure talent, but in reality, they’ve practiced those shots a million times. 

The same applies to fitness. There’s no magic formula. It’s years—decades—of clean eating, disciplined training, and consistent effort. 

It never gets easier. You just get better. 

Whether we’re entrepreneurs, professionals, or artists, the lesson is clear—true mastery is not about ease but about persistence. 

The ease you see is hard-earned. 

"It's only a point," Federer said. In tennis, just like in life, not every serve goes our way. What matters is what we do next. 

Do you dwell on the missed shot, or do you prepare for the next one? 

Despite his global fame and near-mythical status, Federer speaks about life’s richness beyond the court. There’s something deeply humbling in how he calls himself a father first, cherishing simple joys like driving his kids to school. 

His speech was more than just a pep talk for students. It was a masterclass in resilience, discipline, and perspective—the very principles that built one of the greatest sporting legacies. 

Everything he said is a guide to winning at life. With grace. With excellence. 🤩

The biggest bottleneck in your career isn't skill,

It's this:

You can have all the experience, training, and opportunities -

And still stay stuck if your mindset holds you there.

The good news is you can fix that.

The shift starts small:
A few words you swap in your own head.

Small edits with massive impact.

These 7 mindset shifts change everything:

1. I'm not ready → I'll learn as I go
↳Readiness is a myth. Momentum makes you capable
↳Action: Write down the first 2 messy steps and do them before you feel ready

2. This is a problem → This is a puzzle
↳One feels heavy, the other invites curiosity
↳Action: Ask, "What are 3 possible ways this could work?" before labeling it stuck

3. What if I mess up? → I've practiced for this
↳Fear shifts to focus when you see the reps behind you
↳Action: Keep a "reps list" of past situations you handled well and reread it before big moments

4. I don't know how → I can learn how
↳A skill gap is temporary. A fixed belief is permanent
↳Action: Block 20 minutes to watch or read one resource today

5. This won't work → I'll find a way
↳A test, not a dead end
↳Action: List one fallback option before you start - now you have safety to move

6. This is a risk → This is an opportunity
↳Same facts, different emotional weight
↳Action: Write the best case scenario on paper. Keep it visible while you decide

7. I failed → I learned
↳A mistake shows you what to fix, it doesn't define you
↳Action: After any setback, ask: "What's the 1 thing I'd do differently next time?"


Big changes usually start with small mental edits.

Which of these do you need most right now?

---

♻️ Share this to inspire others to shift their mindset.

And follow me George Stern for more.

𝗪𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗛𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗜 𝗦𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗕𝗲𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗲?
This is the most crucial question to ask during a semiotic study. Semiotics is the study of how signs and symbols create and communicate meaning.

A small example from everyday life: at my local supermarket, every price tag is black text on a yellow background. In semiotics, black and yellow together often mean warning, caution, or urgency: think hazard signs, bees, wasps, and certain snakes. In retail, that same color combination often signals discounts or special offers. So when you see it, you instinctively think bargain.

But here’s the trick; when every price tag uses that color scheme, it creates the illusion that everything is on sale, even when it’s not. Check the receipt, and the illusion disappears. A subtle, clever piece of retail psychology.

Semiotics helps us ask not just what something means, but:
• Where did this meaning come from?
• Why is it being used here?
• What reaction was it meant to provoke?
• What does it remind people of?

It’s a way of tracing cultural cues back to their origins, understanding how they’ve found their way into our everyday perceptions.

Grateful to Dr Rachel Lawes and Panos Dimitropoulos for opening my eyes to the ways semiotics shapes retail, shopping, and even the clever tricks that have us buying things we never planned to.

Pixar’s Elio just delivered the studio’s weakest box office debut—a surprise, given its glowing reviews. But it’s also a mirror to a wider shift in global storytelling.

Original films are up against towering franchises and reboots that dominate attention, marketing, and revenue. Here's what’s fueling this transformation in how we watch—and what we choose to watch:

𝗙𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗹𝗶𝗮𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵 𝗔𝗹𝗴𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗵𝗺𝘀
Streaming services lean into known titles. Their recommendation engines reward the predictable, nudging audiences away from fresh ideas.

𝗛𝘆𝗽𝗲𝗿-𝗖𝘂𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻
Viewers now craft their own entertainment ecosystems. In a world of niche tastes, shared experiences often come from big franchise events.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗹 𝗚𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻
Younger viewers were raised in cinematic universes. Their cultural memories are shaped by continuity—and studios are meeting that demand with more of the same.

𝗕𝗼𝗿𝗱𝗲𝗿𝗹𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗕𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗸𝗯𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀
Franchise films are easier to market across global markets. Big-budget originals face a steeper climb when they don’t come with built-in recognition.

𝗠𝗼𝘃𝗶𝗲 𝗠𝗶𝘀𝘀-𝗢𝘂𝘁
Going to the movies needs to feel like an experience worth having. Blockbusters create urgency and conversation. Originals? They need to work harder to be seen.

𝗢𝗿𝗶𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗮 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗰𝗲—𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗻𝘂𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗶𝘁 𝗿𝗶𝘀𝗸𝘀 𝗯𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗻𝗼𝗿𝗺. 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗶𝘁 𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗻𝗲𝘄 𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗮𝘀 𝗳𝗲𝗲𝗹 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮𝗴𝗮𝗶𝗻?

𝗖𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗮’𝘀 𝗦𝗵𝗼𝗽𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗕𝗼𝗼𝗺: 𝗧𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗶𝘀𝗺 𝗠𝗲𝗲𝘁𝘀 𝗥𝗲𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗹 𝗦𝘂𝗿𝗴𝗲
International visitors are increasingly treating China as a premier shopping destination, drawn by a mix of tradition and innovation. From handcrafted teacups to folding-screen smartphones, foreign tourists are making shopping a key part of their travel experience.

With visa-free travel expanding and social media fueling “China tours,” foreign visitors are embracing a “tourism plus shopping” model. During the May Day holiday, foreign arrivals surged by 43.1%, with spending in Shanghai alone soaring 211.6% year-on-year.

Tax refunds, seamless mobile payments, and the global appeal of “Made in China” products—from smart home devices to silk attire—are transforming China into a premier shopping destination. Some travelers even organize group shopping trips, ensuring they return home with the latest innovations and cultural treasures.

As accessibility improves, China’s retail landscape is becoming an increasingly powerful draw for global consumers.

Like many of you, I was deeply saddened to hear about the tragic crash of Air India Flight Al171, which was on its way from Ahmedabad to London.

The flight had 242 people on board (230 passengers and 12 crew members)-included 169 Indian nationals, 53 British nationals, 7 Portuguese nationals, and 1 Canadian national- and sadly, there are no known survivors.

People from different parts of the world were on that flight. Behind every name was a family, a story, a future... and someone waiting for them to come home. 
It's hard to put into words how deeply painful this is even for those of us not directly connected. Grief like this reminds us just how fragile life really is.

In moments like these, I we should remember. Life is unpredictable - and incredibly precious.

Let us all take a quiet moment today to reflect, to be grateful for life, and to extend kindness to those around us

🏆 Embracing Resilience – My First ICN Experience at 43! 🏆

At the age of 43, stepping onto the ICN stage for the first time was a dream come true. This journey wasn’t just about competing; it was a test of resilience, discipline, and personal growth. I’m incredibly proud to share memorable experiences of my life & few medals as well 😎

Fit couple - Gold (Partner - Shilpa Kansal)
Men's Runway Model - Gold
Transformation Male - Gold
Men's Fitness 30+ - Bronze 
Men's Fitness First Timer - 5th

Achieving this milestone wouldn’t have been possible without the unwavering support and guidance of some exceptional people:
✨ My Fitness Coach, Co-Founder at Fittr & INFS Bala Dabbedi 
✨ My Posing Coach, IT Professional & fitness enthusiast Mathanagopalan Ravichandran 
✨ ICN President, Jay Acharya
✨ My Family, A special thank you to my family for their unconditional support throughout this journey. 
Shilpa Kansal 

This experience has been a powerful reminder of the importance of resilience—a quality that extends far beyond the fitness world. In our careers and personal lives, resilience empowers us to embrace challenges, adapt to change, and strive for excellence, no matter the circumstances.

To everyone reading this: whether it's stepping onto a stage, taking on a new career challenge, or pursuing a passion, it’s never too late to push your boundaries. Age, like any obstacle, is just a number.

I am deeply grateful for this journey and for the opportunity to experience the joy of competing, the satisfaction of overcoming hurdles, and the pride of achieving what once seemed impossible.

Here’s to resilience, growth, and the pursuit of our dreams! 💪🌟

Let’s test something. Go to your favorite 5 star hotel’s Instagram page or booking listing. Count how many photos you see of the breakfast buffet, the spa lobby, or a latte with perfectly dusted cocoa art. Now count how many pictures you find of the gym.

Exactly.

As someone who has spent over 20 years in this industry, opening hotels, rebranding them, building their reputations, and creating content pretty much 24/7, I still find myself baffled by this particular blind spot. We spend fortunes on treadmills, wellness consultants, Technogym equipment, even scented towels. And then… we don’t show it?

I just got back from my staycation and yes, I was reminded, again, of what I wanted to rant about.

Here’s the thing. I’m not a fitness influencer. But I am a hotel guest. And when I book my stay, I look at three things in this order:
 1. Location
 2. Wellness facilities (yes, the gym matters)
 3. Room size and vibe

And I’m not alone. Wellness is no longer a trend-it’s a lifestyle, and for many, a non negotiable. Guests want to know what they’re walking into. Yet most hotel content skips the gym entirely. We’ll see 25 angles of a croissant and 14 shots of an empty ballroom before we see a single decent image of the fitness space if we see one at all.

From a content and commercial standpoint, this is a missed opportunity. And dare I say, a revenue leak. Because I know I’ve skipped so many bookings due to the lack of gym visibility. And I know others who have, too.

It doesn’t take much. A quick reel of someone mid workout, a carousel showing off your recovery zone, even a highlight tour of the space. Bonus points if you actually tell us who it’s for: jet lagged execs, spin addicts, gym rats, or just parents escaping the breakfast buffet chaos.

We’ve spent years reimagining hospitality around experiences, lifestyle, and personalization. And yet, in 2025, the gym is still treated like an afterthought. Maybe it’s time we moved it closer to the front.

Because let’s be honest, that same old croissant isn’t booking the room. But a gym that makes me want to train? That just might.

We want to work out every day. Just like we want to eat. Sleep. Breathe. 

So please, show us the gym.

This Sunday, I watched India beat Pakistan by 7 wickets in the Asia Cup.

Pakistan managed 127/9. India chased it down with 131/3.

But what stayed with me wasn’t the scorecard.

It was watching Kuldeep Yadav tear through Pakistan’s batting lineup - 3 wickets for just 18 runs. This guy had been waiting for his moment, and when it came, he grabbed it.

There’s something about watching athletes trust their instincts under pressure that gets to me. 
That split second when all the practice meets the defining moment and you either rise or you don’t.

Suryakumar Yadav finished unbeaten on 47. Abhishek Sharma contributed 31. Neither had perfect conditions. Neither waited for the “right” moment.

They just played their game when it mattered.

Reminds me why I sometimes make my best calls at work when I stop overthinking and just go with what feels right.

Some of our biggest wins have come from trusting ourselves rather than waiting for perfect data.

Anyway, hell of a match. Sometimes the scoreboard doesn’t tell the real story.

What did you think of Kuldeep’s performance? The guy was on fire.

If wealth had a passport, it would say: UAE.



Why are global companies obsessed with Dubai?

Well, for starters, it gives access to two billion people in one region. Companies aren't just entering Dubai; they're using it to conquer entire regions, like the Middle East, Africa, South Asia, and even parts of Europe.

That’s the Dubai formula.

When people say “Dubai connects East and West,” I used to think it was just marketing.

Until I realized:

> You can reach 2 billion people within 4 hours of flying from Dubai (that’s one third of the world.) That’s breakfast in Dubai, meetings in Nairobi, and dinner in Mumbai.

> You don't have to pay income tax, capital gains tax, or inheritance tax.

> Top-tier infrastructure: 2 world class airports + Jebel Ali Port

> Zero red tape: duty-free zones, 100% foreign ownership in many sectors

> Massive talent pool: cross-border hiring made easy

> Access to 3 billion+ consumers across emerging and mature markets

Entering Dubai is not entering only one market; it's stepping into a region. Dubai not only gives people ease of doing business but also speed.

No wonder companies set up here to scale faster: logistics are tighter, regulations are cleaner, and your markets are literally hours away.

And once you see it that way, it's hard to unsee.

Do you run a business in Dubai?

A German psychologist spent years memorizing nonsense syllables.


His self-experiment in 1885 revealed something shocking about human memory.

The results explain why most training programs fail - and how to fix them:

The experiment: Hermann Ebbinghaus tested his own memory using meaningless combinations of letters.

He memorized lists, then tested himself at different intervals. What he discovered changed our understanding of learning forever. 

The brutal truth: Within an hour of learning new information people tend to forget up to 50% of it. Within 24 hours, this can increase to 70% .

Within a week, they forget up to 90% of what they "learned". Your brain literally dumps most new information within hours.

Why this happens: Your brain is constantly filtering what's "worth keeping."

Unless information gets reinforced, it assumes it's not important.

The sharpest decline in retention occurs within the first twenty minutes and is significant within the first hour.

Here's the simple technique that changes everything:

Spaced repetition.
Instead of cramming once, you review at strategic intervals:
- Review #1: Within 24 hours
- Review #2: After 3 days
- Review #3: After 1 week
- Review #4: After 1 month
Instead of trying to cram all the information in at once, repeat the learning multiple times after the initial lesson. This strategy helps to increase memory retention.

Each review "resets" the forgetting curve, making memories stronger and longer-lasting.

Why most training fails: Companies spend millions on one-time workshops, then wonder why nothing sticks.

Employees forget 90% within a week because there's no follow-up.

How I apply this: 
→ Set calendar reminders to review key concepts 1 day, 3 days, and 1 week after learning 
→ Use spaced repetition apps like Anki for important information
→ Break training into smaller chunks with built-in review cycles 
→ Take notes, then revisit them at increasing intervals

The difference between forgetting and mastering isn't talent. It's timing.

What's one skill you learned but lost because you didn't review it?

Leaders, ignore these signs at your own risk

7 signs the worst parts of your culture are getting louder:

1. Poor Communication
- Lack of transparency from management.
- Infrequent or unclear updates on company goals.
- Limited opportunities for employee feedback.

2. High Turnover Rates
- Frequent resignations or layoffs.
- Difficulty retaining top talent.
- Constantly hiring to fill the same positions.

3. Unmanageable Workloads
- Employees frequently working overtime.
- Unrealistic deadlines and expectations.
- Lack of resources and support.

4. Office Politics
- Favoritism and nepotism.
- Undermining and backstabbing among colleagues.
- Decisions based on personal relationships, not merit.

5. Lack of Recognition
- Employees' achievements go unnoticed.
- Infrequent or nonexistent praise from management.
- No reward system for exceptional performance.

6. Low Morale
- Widespread employee dissatisfaction.
- High levels of stress and burnout.
- Lack of enthusiasm and engagement.

7. Poor Work-Life Balance

Yesterday’s poll revealed something clear:
leaders are split on how to play Dubai’s office cycle:

𝗕𝘂𝘆 → voters want capital growth & long-term security.

The reality? There isn’t one perfect model — it depends on where you are in your business journey. What’s clear is companies aren’t just chasing space; they’re seeking 𝗲𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆.

In a market that has already seen 2,682 office sales YTD at an average of AED 1,746 psf, and156K lease contracts worth AED 6.7B, demand is clearly strong across both ownership and leasing.

With 𝗗𝗔𝗠𝗔𝗖 𝗗𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘁, businesses gain a rare mix:

It’s not just real estate — 𝗶𝘁’𝘀 𝗮 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗴𝗿𝗼𝘄𝘁𝗵.

“Can you give me a 12-page report on this?”

Of course.

Open ChatGPT, Copilot, whatever. Tap in a few prompts. Boom. Twelve glorious pages of well-formatted, confidence drenched waffle.

Three charts. A quote from McKinsey. Something that looks suspiciously like insight but could also be AI generated filler.

Done.

Five minutes later?

Your manager hops onto ChatGPT.

“Can you summarise this for me?”

Naturally.

Open ChatGPT again. “Summarise this.” Output: three bullet points and a vague recommendation about alignment.

This, ladies and gentlemen, is the modern workplace.

AI isn’t destroying jobs. It’s just exposing how much of what we do never needed doing in the first place.

The meetings that could’ve been emails. 

The emails that could’ve been nothing. 

The slide decks with 74 animations to say: “Sales are fine.”

AI didn’t create the fluff.

It just made it obvious.

We’ve built entire careers around making things look impressive instead of making them useful.

Now we have a tool that says, “You want to pretend? I can pretend faster.”

And suddenly, everyone’s nervous.

Because when your whole value is formatting busywork into bullet points, AI isn’t competition.

It’s a spotlight.

And for some?

It’s the first time their job description has been seen in full daylight. Only to realise it’s mostly smoke.

♻️ Repost this if you’ve ever read a report and wondered, “Why does this exist?”

Or just follow Edward Frank Morris for more AI insights, sarcasm, and the occasional professional AI woe.

David's accolades include the ARDA Community Service Award, UCF Rosen College of Hospitality Hall of Fame, and Ernst & Young's Entrepreneur of the Year. He also leads the Westgate Foundation and Victoria’s Voice.
